employees.rationale: Companies with 11-50 employees are in the sweet spot where they've proven their business model and have budget, but their sales teams are still small enough (1-5 reps) to need automation without requiring enterprise-level customization. The 51-200 range captures slightly larger companies entering growth mode who are scaling their sales teams rapidly.

revenue.rationale: The $1M-$5M revenue range indicates companies with proven product-market fit and actual budget for sales tools, but not yet complex enough to need enterprise solutions. At this stage, they're focused on scaling efficiently. $5M-$20M companies are ideal expansion targets as they grow into our platform.

growthStageIndicators.stageRationale: Series A-B companies have just raised capital and are in active growth mode - they're hiring sales teams, investing in tools, and have urgency to show revenue growth. Bootstrapped profitable companies are also excellent fits as they're disciplined with spending but will invest in tools with clear ROI. Both segments have proven their model and have budget authority. We avoid seed stage (too early, no budget) and Series C+ (need enterprise solutions).

geographicTargeting.marketPenetration: Primary focus is the United States where 80% of our current customers are located and we have the strongest sales/support infrastructure. We can serve Canadian customers but without localized support. Future expansion to Europe is planned but not current focus. Local presence not required - fully remote sales model.

industryFocus.industryRationale: Technology/SaaS companies (60% of our customers) understand software value and adopt quickly. They have similar tech stacks (Salesforce, HubSpot) making integration seamless. Professional Services firms (consulting, agencies) have high-volume outbound needs for new client acquisition. Marketing/Advertising agencies do constant prospecting and appreciate our multi-channel approach. All three industries are comfortable with SaaS tools and have fast decision cycles.
industryFocus.avoidRationale: Government has complex procurement processes (6-12 month cycles) and requires on-premise solutions we don't offer. Non-profits have limited budgets and different buying priorities. Hospitality industry has been deprioritized due to high churn rates (seasonal business, thin margins) and low success rates with our platform.

companyType.implications: B2B companies are our core focus because they have: (1) longer sales cycles where our nurture automation adds value, (2) higher deal values justifying our pricing, (3) decision-makers accessible on LinkedIn, (4) need for multi-touch campaigns we excel at. B2C companies have different buying psychology and channels (paid ads, influencers) that don't align with our outbound focus. B2B2C can work if their primary motion is B2B partnerships.

budgetProfile.budgetAlignment: Our $499/month starting price ($6K annually) sits at the bottom of this range, leaving room for upsells to higher tiers ($12K-$24K annually). Companies budgeting $5K-$25K for sales tools view us as affordable compared to enterprise platforms ($50K+) but premium compared to basic tools (<$2K). This budget range indicates serious investment in sales infrastructure without requiring extensive procurement.
budgetProfile.budgetCycle: Most companies budget in Q4 for the following year, but can access 'growth budgets' mid-year if they're exceeding targets. Fast-growing companies (our target) often have discretionary budgets for tools that show quick ROI. Typical approval: VP Sales or Revenue can approve <$25K without executive/board approval.

decisionVelocity.implication: The 1-4 week decision cycle aligns perfectly with our sales process: Week 1 (demo), Week 2 (trial), Week 3 (evaluation), Week 4 (close). This velocity indicates companies with: (1) clear pain and urgency, (2) streamlined decision-making (VP level can decide), (3) existing budget or easy budget access, (4) comfort with SaaS buying. Longer cycles (3+ months) usually indicate enterprise complexity, committee decisions, or lack of urgency - all red flags for our model.
decisionVelocity.urgencyFactors: Fast decisions driven by: active hiring of sales reps who need tools immediately, recent funding creating growth pressure, poor current results forcing change, competitive threats requiring faster outbound, leadership changes bringing new priorities. Companies move slow when: unclear ROI, no budget owner, too many stakeholders, annual contract lock-in with current tool.

marketSize.methodology: User estimated 10K-50K companies (midpoint: 30K). Applied filters: B2B companies (70% of total = 21K), Technology/Professional Services/Marketing industries in US (80% of filtered = 16.8K), Series A-B or bootstrapped with $1M+ revenue (50% of filtered = 8.4K), actively hiring sales roles in last 6 months (40% = 3.4K). TAM = 28.5K companies matching firmographic criteria. SAM (serviceable) = 30% of TAM based on our current market penetration capability and geographic reach = 8,550 companies. Confidence is medium due to reliance on user estimate and industry data approximations.

criteria.scoring: Perfect fit (20 pts): 11-50 employees. Good fit (15 pts): 51-200 employees. Acceptable (10 pts): 1-10 or 201-500 employees. Poor fit (5 pts): 501-1000. Disqualified (0 pts): 1000+ employees (enterprise complexity).

Perfect fit (20 pts): $1M-$5M revenue. Good fit (15 pts): $5M-$20M revenue. Acceptable (10 pts): $20M-$50M or bootstrapped <$1M with funding. Poor fit (5 pts): <$500K revenue. Disqualified (0 pts): $100M+ (enterprise).

Perfect fit (25 pts): Technology/SaaS. Good fit (20 pts): Professional Services or Marketing/Advertising. Acceptable (15 pts): Financial Services, Healthcare, or other B2B. Poor fit (10 pts): Retail, Manufacturing. Disqualified (0 pts): Government, Non-profit, Hospitality.

Perfect fit (20 pts): Series A or Series B. Good fit (15 pts): Bootstrapped/Profitable with growth. Acceptable (10 pts): Series C or Seed with clear traction. Poor fit (5 pts): Pre-revenue or Mature/Public. Disqualified (0 pts): Companies in decline or pivot mode.

Perfect fit (15 pts): United States (any state). Good fit (12 pts): Canada. Acceptable (8 pts): English-speaking countries (UK, Australia). Poor fit (5 pts): Europe (time zone challenges). Disqualified (0 pts): APAC or regions we don't serve.

firmographicScoring.scoringFormula: Sum all factor scores. 90-100 = A+ (perfect fit, prioritize immediately). 75-89 = A (strong fit, high priority). 60-74 = B (good fit, pursue actively). 45-59 = C (acceptable fit, pursue if capacity). 30-44 = D (marginal fit, nurture only). 0-29 = F (poor fit, disqualify). Use this score to prioritize leads in Scout and route to appropriate sales motion.
